com.sri.ai.expresso.api

Interface Expression

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Comparable<java.lang.Object>, java.io.Serializable
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Bound, Constraint, Context, CountingFormula, ExistentiallyQuantifiedFormula, ExtensionalSet, FunctionApplication, IntensionalSet, LambdaExpression, Monomial, Polynomial, QuantifiedExpression, QuantifiedExpressionWithABody, RangeAndExceptionsSet, SingleVariableConstraint, Symbol, SyntacticFunctionApplication, Tuple, UniversallyQuantifiedFormula
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractConstraint, AbstractExpression, AbstractExpressionWrapper, AbstractExtensionalBound, AbstractExtensionalSet, AbstractIntensionalBound, AbstractIntensionalSet, AbstractNonQuantifiedExpression, AbstractQuantifiedExpression, AbstractQuantifiedExpressionWithABody, AbstractSingleVariableConstraint, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithBinaryAtoms, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithBinaryAtomsIncludingEquality, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithDependentNormalizedAtoms, AbstractSingleVariableConstraintWithIndependentNormalizedAtoms, AbstractSingleVariableNumericConstraint, CompleteMultiVariableContext, DefaultCountingFormula, DefaultExistentiallyQuantifiedFormula, DefaultExtensionalBound, DefaultExtensionalMultiSet, DefaultExtensionalUniSet, DefaultFunctionApplication, DefaultIntensionalBound, DefaultIntensionalMultiSet, DefaultIntensionalUniSet, DefaultLambdaExpression, DefaultMonomial, DefaultMultiVariableConstraint, DefaultPolynomial, DefaultSymbol, DefaultSyntacticFunctionApplication, DefaultTuple, DefaultUniversallyQuantifiedFormula, DifferenceArithmeticLiteralSide, LazySampledFunction, MultiVariableContextWithCheckedProperty, RangeAndExceptionsSet.DefaultRangeAndExceptionsSet, RangeAndExceptionsSet.Empty, RangeAndExceptionsSet.Singleton, SingleVariableConstraintForTheoryWithoutAtoms, SingleVariableDifferenceArithmeticConstraint, SingleVariableEqualityConstraint, SingleVariableLinearRealArithmeticConstraint, SingleVariablePropositionalConstraint, TrueContext

    @Beta
public interface Expression
extends java.lang.Cloneable, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<java.lang.Object>
    An Expression is an algebraic expression based on a syntax tree.
    Author:
    braz

      • replace

        Expression replace(com.google.common.base.Function<Expression,Expression> replacementFunction,
                   boolean onlyTheFirstOne,
                   PruningPredicate prunePredicate,
                   boolean ignoreTopExpression,

      • replace

        Expression replace(com.google.common.base.Function<Expression,Expression> replacementFunction,
                   ReplacementFunctionMaker makeSpecificSubExpressionAndSyntacticContextReplacementFunction,
                   PruningPredicate prunePredicate,
                   PruningPredicateMaker makeSpecificSubExpressionAndSyntacticContextPrunePredicate,
                   boolean onlyTheFirstOne,
                   boolean ignoreTopExpression,
                   boolean replaceOnChildrenBeforeTopExpression,
                   com.sri.ai.util.base.TernaryProcedure<Expression,Expression,Registry> listener,
                   Registry registry)
        Returns the result of replacing one or all sub-expressions of this expression according to a replacement function. The method works by traversing every sub-expression of this expression (including the expression itself, unless the argument ignoreTopExpression is true) and calling a replacement function on it. If the replacement function returns exactly the same expression object, then nothing happens. If a new expression object is returned by the replacement function, then it replaces the original sub-expression. Note that, because expression objects are immutable, replacing a sub-expression S by a new sub-expression S' will necessarily replace its parent P as well by a new version P' that is equal to P but for having S' where S used to be. The parent's replacement trigger its own parent to be replaced and so on, all the way to the root. The replacement of parents happens automatically and the user need not worry about making it happen. Note that new sub-expressions replacing old ones are not further examined and left as is. If they contain sub-expressions that would be replaced themselves by the replacement function, these sub-expressions are not replaced. For example, if a replacement function replaces expressions "a" by an expression "f(a)", calling this method with this replacement function on "g(a,a)" produces "g(f(a),f(a))", with the "a"s in the result not being replaced. If the user wishes this to happen, she must re-run the function on the result. To this basic functionality the method adds several more detailed options (note the many auxiliary methods that do not require some of these options to be specified, using defaults for them): A prune predicate can be provided that will be invoked on a sub-expression and its Registry and indicates whether it (and its descendants) should be ignored. Sometimes we wish the replacement and prune functions to be updated or changed accordingly to the characteristics of the sub-expressions or trees they are being used on. For this reason, the replace method can take two function arguments, makeSpecificSubExpressionAndSyntacticContextReplacementFunction and makeSpecificSubExpressionAndSyntacticContextPrunePredicate, which take this expression, the replacement function or pruning predicate, and the current sub-expression, and provides a new replacement function or prune predicate to be used on that sub-expression and its descendants. This is a more advanced and less commonly used feature. The argument onlyTheFirstOne allows us to choose to replace only the first sub-expression for which the replacement function returns a distinct object, or to continue examining all sub-expressions. We can provide a listener procedure that gets notified of every replacement.
        Parameters:
        makeSpecificSubExpressionAndSyntacticContextPrunePredicate - Takes the current expression, the current replacement function and the sub-expression and its registry about to be processed (the top one inclusive), and returns the pruning predicate to be used for that specific sub-expression.
        replaceOnChildrenBeforeTopExpression - indicate whether to replace in sub-expression before replacing top expression.
        replacementFunction - takes a expression and returns a new expression, or itself in case no replacement is warranted. Make it an instance of ReplacementFunctionWithContextuallyUpdatedProcess if it uses the contextual symbols and variables, so that the registry gets properly extended.
        makeSpecificSubExpressionAndSyntacticContextReplacementFunction: - Takes the current expression, the current replacement function and the sub-expression and its registry about to be processed (the top one inclusive), and returns the replacement function to be used for that specific sub-expression.
        prunePredicate - a predicate evaluating as true for sub-expressions that should be pruned (that is, ignored).
        makeSpecificSubExpressionAndSyntacticContextPrunePredicate: - Takes the current prune predicate and the sub-expression and its registry about to be processed (the top one inclusive), and returns the prune predicate to be used for that specific sub-expression.
        onlyTheFirstOne - if true, replaces at most one sub-expression.
        ignoreTopExpression - does not try to replace this expression as a whole; examines sub-expressions only.
        replaceOnChildrenBeforeTopExpression - recurse replacement function on sub-expressions before using it on top expression.
        listener - binary procedure receiving original and replacement expression every time such a replacement occurs. If a sub-expression is replaced, it is invoked for that sub-expression as well as for all its "super-expressions", since they are all being replaced by a new expression.
        registry - the registry, used here for defining what is a sub-expression of what.

      • getSyntacticFormType

        java.lang.Object getSyntacticFormType()
        Indicates what syntactic form the expression is. Syntactic forms are the primitive types of expressions in a logic. For example, in FOL we have the forms: term, predicate, simple formula, quantified formula, etc. HOL typically has function applications and lambda expressions as its basic syntactic forms.

      • getSyntaxTree

        SyntaxTree getSyntaxTree()

      • getImmediateSubExpressionsIterator

        java.util.Iterator<Expression> getImmediateSubExpressionsIterator()

      • replaceSymbol

        Expression replaceSymbol(Expression symbol,
                         Expression newSymbol,
                         Registry registry)
        Renames all occurrences of a symbol, including when it is declared. For example, renaming p by q in for all p(X) in People : happy(p(X)) results in for all q(X) in People : happy(q(X)).
        Parameters:
        symbol -
        newSymbol -
        registry -
        Returns:
        the result of renaming symbol as newSymbol everywhere in expression.

      • getFunctor

        Expression getFunctor()
        Returns the functor if the expression is a function application, or null otherwise.

      • getFunctorOrSymbol

        Expression getFunctorOrSymbol()
        Returns the functor if the expression is a function application, or the symbol otherwise. It assumes that the expression is of one or the other type.

      • hasFunctor

        boolean hasFunctor(java.lang.Object functor)
        Indicates whether expression is a function application with given functor.

      • getArguments

        java.util.List<Expression> getArguments()
        Returns the arguments of a function application expression if this is one.

      • numberOfArguments

        int numberOfArguments()
        Same as getArguments().size(), but potentially more efficient.

      • get

        Expression get(int i)
        Same as getArguments().get(i), but potentially more efficient.

      • set

        Expression set(int i,
               Expression newIthArgument)
        If this is a function application, returns an expression equal to this one, but for replacing the i-th argument by the given one. Generates an error otherwise.

      • getValue

        java.lang.Object getValue()
        Returns the value of an expression if it is a Symbol, and null otherwise. The reason it is available at the Expression is that is it a very commonly used method and casting makes the code harder to read.

      • isStringLiteral

        boolean isStringLiteral()
        Determine if the value of the Symbol is a string literal.
        Returns:
        true if the Symbol represents a String literal (i.e. parsed with surrounding double quotes, quoted symbols use single quotes and are not string literals), false otherwise.

      • booleanValue

        boolean booleanValue()
        Returns the value of the symbol as a boolean. An error is thrown if the value of the symbol is not a boolean.

      • intValue

        int intValue()
        Returns the value of the symbol as an int. This may involve rounding or truncation. An error is thrown if the value of the symbol is not a number.

      • longValue

        long longValue()
        Returns the value of the symbol as a long. This may involve rounding or truncation. An error is thrown if the value of the symbol is not a number.

      • intValueExact

        int intValueExact()
           throws java.lang.ArithmeticException
        Returns the value of the symbol as an int. This may involve rounding or truncation. An java.lang.ArithmeticException.ArithmeticException is thrown if the value of the symbol is not a number OR not an integral value.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArithmeticException

      • doubleValue

        double doubleValue()
        Returns the value of the symbol as a double. This may involve rounding or truncation. An error is thrown if the value of the symbol is not a number.

      • rationalValue

        com.sri.ai.util.math.Rational rationalValue()
        Returns the value of the symbol as a Rational. An error is thrown if the value of the symbol is not a number.

      • equals

        boolean equals(java.lang.Object object)
        Indicates whether two expressions are syntactically equal, allowing comparisons to Strings as well as a convenience (this is equivalent to comparing to the Symbol obtained from the String). Note that the comparison to String violates the specification of equals, since s.equals(e) for s and e String and Expression respectively will always return false, even if e.equals(s) returns true. However, this should not be a problem if Strings and Expressions are not mixed in containers or algorithms relying on equals, which would not be possible even if the comparison to String convenience were omitted. TODO: In the future we may replace this convenience by a method specific to comparing to Strings, which would be more explicit. This will take some work as all invocations of equals on Strings would have to be replaced by this new method.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
        Parameters:
        object - the object to compare this expression to.
        Returns:
        whether the two objects are considered equal.
